tossups.question: One visitor trying to get to this place ends up in New France instead on his first attempt; when he finally reaches it, he argues with Domingo Gonsales that humans have no souls. A wanna-be playwright alerts his inventor neighbor to a “zazzoo” humming noise he is making before they get high on some fungus in this place. They travel to this place via a capsule of the gravity-defying Cavorite, and find cow-like creatures herded by insectoid natives, whom Bedford escapes, in an (*) H. G. Wells novel named after “The First Men in” this place. Cyrano de Bergerac and Baron Munchausen claimed to have traveled to this place, which is hit in the eye in a Georges Melies movie. Galileo discovered craters on this body, which was probably created by a collision with the Earth. For 10 points, name this body which was visited by Neil Armstrong.

Two tents and their shadows are shown above a scale in one painting named for these people. The same artist showed a man in a tan suit in front of these people with a ball on a red wavy background; that was de Chirico depicting these “Mysterious” people. In another painting, one of these people stuffs her fingers into her mouth as she gazes down at a turtle. Thin smokestacks are in the background in a painting named for these people in which a man in a (*) black hat lies next to a red dog. One entry in a series of depictions of them shows them in front of a white sheet and in front of blotchy, bright green trees. Seurat depicted these people “at Asnieres” as a sequel to A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte. Leaning trees form a triangle over reclining nude women by a river in, for 10 points, a Cezanne painting named for what “Large” figures?
tossups.answer: bathers [accept Mysterious Bathers, Bathers at Asnieres, Bathers with Turtle, Large Bathers, prompt on “nudes” or “swimmers”or any relevant description]
tossups.answer_formatted: bathers [accept Mysterious Bathers, Bathers at Asnieres, Bathers with Turtle, Large Bathers, prompt on “nudes or swimmers”or any relevant description]
acceptable: Mysterious Bathers, Bathers at Asnieres, Bathers with Turtle, Large Bathers, prompt on “nudes

tossups.question: One poem set during this conflict describes “crank, pivot, and screw, and calculations” in “War now placed … among the trades and artisans.” Another poem from this war asks “Would the singer attempt to sing? Would the lawyer rise in the court?” One poem set during this conflict exclaims “What like a bullet can undeceive!” and ends by saying that “over them the swallows skim, while all is hushed” on the title battlefield. “Beat! Beat! (*) Drums” was written by an author who described his time treating this war’s wounded. In another poem, an old woman declares, “Shoot, if you must, this old gray head, / But spare your country’s flag” -- that poem is “Barbara Frietchie.” For 10 points, name this conflict written about by Walt Whitman and John Whittier, as well as Julia Ward Howe in her “Battle Hymn of the Republic.”
tossups.answer: the American Civil War [grudgingly prompt on “The War of Northern Aggression” or “The War Between the States”]
tossups.answer_formatted: the American Civil War [grudgingly prompt on “The War of Northern Aggression” or “The War Between the States”]

tossups.question: A major leader of this religious movement named Tävibo preached that the disappearance of another race would coincide with the resurrection of the dead among his people. James Mooney issued a study of this religion. Si Tanka died while fleeing this group’s persecution. This religion prescribed a sweat bath purification and a series of group visions that would imbue a (*) shirt with wakan, or mystery, that would make its wearer invulnerable. A book by Dee Brown describes how the US government’s opposition to this religion resulted in the death of a certain chief at the hands of a Standing Rock policeman as well as a subsequent event in which the deaf Black Coyote did not hear calls to disarm. For 10 points, Wovoka revived what terpsichorean religious movement whose adherents were slaughtered in the Wounded Knee Massacre?
tossups.answer: Ghost Dance of 1890 movement [or Nanissáanah; or Spirit Dance; or Round Dance]
tossups.answer_formatted: Ghost Dance of 1890 movement [or Nanissáanah; or Spirit Dance; or Round Dance]

tossups.question: CD1d is considered a nonclassical version of this complex. By evolutionary coincidence, the HFE gene lies very near the gene encoding one part of this complex, meaning that hemochromatosis is linked to some alleles of it. Monomers of this complex are biotinylated and bound to a streptavidin-fluorophore complex in a flow cytometric tetramer assay to detect antigen-specific cells. Erp57, tapasin, and TAP are some of the components of this structure’s namesake “loading complex,” which attaches immunoproteasome-derived (*) peptides to it. This complex binds to the T-cell receptor, and its Type 2 is only present on antigen-presenting cells. For 10 points, name this highly variable protein complex used to present antigens, which comes in Class I and Class II varieties.

An alcoholic defrocked priest lives wildly with cavaliers at Ekeby until finally returning to his pulpit in one novel from this country. One novel from this country depicts Leonardo da Vinci as “Bernardo”; that novel’s narrator is imprisoned for killing Teodora after she sleeps with Don Riccardo. This country, home of Gosta Berling’s Saga, was home to the author of a novel about the 26-inch tall misanthrope Piccolini, (*) The Dwarf. In another novel from this country, the main character quits a civil service job to work as a journalist and befriends some artists who meet at the title Bohemian bar. This country’s most famous author wrote about Arvind Falk in The Red Room and is known for plays like The Father and Miss Julie. For 10 points, name this home country of Selma Lagerlof, Par Lagerkvist, and August Strindberg.

Comic songs in this opera include an innkeeper’s love song to a goose and a nurse’s song about a bug and a gnat. One character in this opera is caught trying to change the description of a Wanted poster of himself. This work was originally rejected for having no main female characters, which was fixed when the composer added a romantic meeting between Marina and the monk Grigory. Vaarlam and Misail sing a drinking song about the siege of (*) Kazan in this work. This work’s prologue ends with a chorus of “Glory” using polymeter and the whole-tone scale. This work’s title character sings the monologue “I have attained supreme power” before hallucinating his murdered predecessor. This opera ends with the title character giving the throne to his son Fyodor. For 10 points, name this Modest Mussorgsky opera about the titular czar during the Time of Troubles.

One person born into this family allegedly showed her vagina to members of the Orsis family while defending Ravaldino to show that she was unmoved by threats against her children. That “Tigress of Forli” from this family was later captured in a siege by Cesare Borgia and had earlier occupied the Castel Sant’Angelo for her husband, Girolamo Riario, after the death of Pope Sixtus IV. Another member of this family married his niece Bianca to Maximilian I to resist the (*) Italian War of Charles VIII, which he had unwisely encouraged. That leader of this family rose to power after assassinating his nephew, Gian Galeazzo, was nicknamed “the Moor,” and commissioned Leonardo da Vinci’s Last Supper. This family succeeded the Visconti family in its most famous position. For 10 points, name this family that held the Duchy of Milan under Ludovico.

The effect of these substances on elimination and substitution reactions is summarized in the Hughes-Ingold rules. When these substances are simply assumed to be a continuum, the change in free energy from adding one of them equals the sum of sigma times the accessible surface area. COSMO and Generalized Born are implicit models of these substances, whose strength is often given by their dielectric constant. The (*) partition coefficient is used to determine when a compound will move from one of these substances to another. Rotary evaporation is used to remove these substances. Polar aprotic ones like THF are used for SN2 reactions, whose volume appears in the denominator of the equation for calculating molarity. For 10 points, name these substances, of which water is considered the “universal” one, which dissolves solutes.

One man in this novel used to impersonate the wife of the Duke of Vincennes over the phone. A child in this novel tricks a man into thinking that people can pay churches to get specific people sent to hell. That girl, Cordelia, quotes Chesterton about an “unseen hook and an invisible line” holding her brother, who cares for the German soldier Kurt. This novel’s protagonist does architectural sketches of Latin America and has an affair on a cruise ship with the wife of (*) Rex Mottram, Julia. He often visits her alcoholic brother, who in college had thrown up in his window and carried around the teddy bear Aloysius. During WWII, this book’s protagonist is stationed at the estate of the Marchmain family and remembers his friendship with their son Sebastian Flyte. For 10 points, name this novel about Charles Ryder, by Evelyn Waugh.

Note: both composer and type of work required. The tempo marking at the beginning of one of these works simply states that “times change,” likely a reference to a popular epigram at the time. Another one of these works begins with all instruments playing E-B-E-D-flat and contains an unusual second movement minuet and a slow third movement that the composer asked to be played at his funeral. The presto finale of another one of these works is occasionally performed with trumpet and timpani accompaniment and features a theme based on (*) La Chasse du cerf . The premiere of one of these works saw a falling chandelier narrowly miss the audience, giving it the nickname “Miracle.” For 10 points, name these 104 works by an Austrian composer which are often given nicknames such as “Military” and “Surprise.”

According to legend, one of these animals disguised himself as a deer with a firebrand tied to his tail in order to distract people and steal fire from them. After failing to carve fish out of wood, that animal caused Salmon Woman to produce salmon without her husband’s knowledge. One of these animals released men from a clam shell and women from a chiton in order to let the two sexes meet for the first time, and he is later swallowed by a whale. In alternate myths, one of these animals either turns into a (*) clump of dirt in a woman’s drinking water to be reborn as a fussy baby or stabs a seagull with a thorn in order to release the sun, moon, and stars. The Morrigan takes the form of one of these birds, and Huginn and Muninn are two of these birds which report news to Odin. For 10 points, name this animal, a non-Coyote Native American trickster figure.
tossups.answer: raven [or crows; accept Tulukaruq, He’mask’as, Chulyen, Guguyni, Nankil'slas, Kwekwaxa'we, or anything else that turns out to be a Native American term for raven]
tossups.answer_formatted: raven [or crows; accept Tulukaruq, He’mask’as, Chulyen, Guguyni, Nankil'slas, Kwekwaxa'we, or anything else that turns out to be a Native American term for raven]
acceptable: Tulukaruq, He’mask’as, Chulyen, Guguyni, Nankil'slas, Kwekwaxa'we,
anything else that turns out to be a Native American term for raven

tossups.question: This person’s advocacy for a compromise was lambasted as a “fallen star, Lucifer descending from heaven” by Horace Mann. One speech by this person begins by discussing a mariner lost at sea, and later the speaker states that he did not want to see the sun shining on the “broken and dishonored fragments of a once glorious Union.” That speech was sparked by a discussion about the Foot Resolution. This person gave the dedication for the (*) Bunker Hill monument as well as some speeches at Faneuil Hall. In another speech, this person noted that he spoke not as a “Northern man,” but “as an American,” and his greatest speech calls for “Liberty and Union, now and forever, one and inseparable.” This person’s most famous speeches include the 7th of March speech and two against Senator Hayne. For 10 points, name this Massachusetts Senator nicknamed “Black Dan.”

Description acceptable. A spectral method for performing this process uses a set of equations written in terms of spherical harmonics that truncates at a wavenumber of 799. The results of multiple iterations of models used to perform this task can be visualized using a spaghetti plot. A dimensionless parameter called the Exner function can be used to simplify a set of equations governing this process. Numerical models used to perform this task may make use of a vertical coordinate system which is normalized by the surface pressure known as (*) sigma coordinates. The results of this process are usually displayed on prognostic charts. Data is collected for use in this task by radiosondes which are carried by balloons. Modern methods of performing this task locate precipitation using the Doppler effect. For 10 points, name this task performed by meteorologists.
tossups.answer: weather forecasting [or obvious equivalents like predicting the weather; I guess accept atmospheric modeling or equivalents; prompt on “meteorology”]
tossups.answer_formatted: weather forecasting [or obvious equivalents like predicting the weather; I guess accept atmospheric modeling or equivalents; prompt on meteorology]
acceptable: obvious equivalents like predicting the weather

tossups.question: New York Times journalist Rukmini Callimachi mainly covers this organization. A subgroup of it led by the Maute brothers tried to gain control of Marawi City. Members of it often communicate using the app Telegram. This organization publishes the weekly “Naba” newspaper and changed its chief publication to one named “Rumiyah,” or “Rome,” in September 2016. This organization makes signature use of the substance TATP. Brett McGurk is the American special envoy to a (*) coalition against this group. It used to publish a magazine called Dabiq and was recently forced out of its capital at Raqqa. This group blamed American airstrikes for the destruction of the al-Nuri mosque in Mosul, which it held until July 2017. For 10 points, name this terrorist organization led by Abu Bakr al Baghdadi which gained prominence after beheading Westerners.
tossups.answer: ISIS [ISIL; Daesh; Islamic State of Iraq and Syria; Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant; Islamic State of Iraq and al-Sham]
tossups.answer_formatted: ISIS [ISIL; Daesh; Islamic State of Iraq and Syria; Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant; Islamic State of Iraq and al-Sham]

tossups.question: In this novel, a man runs into his servant dancing at a bar, who instantly stops when seen. In this novel, a hotel maid brings a historian to see her son when his college education makes him politically apathetic. The narrator uses a simile about a column of ants continuing even when some of its members die to describe a town’s reaction to the murder of a mask-collecting priest. The protagonist is arrested for hiding ivory in this novel, but is broken out and told “We’re all going to hell, and every man knows this” by (*) Ferdinand, who repays the narrator for his education by helping him escape the country on a steamer that gets attacked. That narrator sleeps with Raymond’s wife Yvette and has his store confiscated by the Big Man, a stand-in for Mobutu Sese Seko. For 10 points, name this V. S. Naipaul novel about the merchant Salim, who lives at the title location.

Two plebeian aediles were added by Julius Caesar in 44 BC to control the market for this good, which was often stored in warehouses called horrea. The goddess Annona was a personification of this commodity. The fourth of the Clodian Laws controlled the price of this commodity. Disruption of the trade of this good by Menas was the chief reason behind the signing of the Pact of Misenum with Sextus Pompeius. This subject of the Lex (*) Frumentaria was derided for causing the populace to “cast off its cares” in the 10th Satire of Juvenal. This good was mainly imported to Rome through the port of Ostia from Egypt and Africa. Gaius Gracchus began the namesake “dole” of this good, which provided it to the poor at low prices. For 10 points, name this good which names a type of popular politics, along with “circus.”
tossups.answer: grain [or bread; cereal; wheat; accept frumentarius and Annona before mention; prompt on “food”; accept clear knowledge equivalents]
tossups.answer_formatted: grain [or bread; cereal; wheat; accept frumentarius or Annona before mention; prompt on food; accept clear knowledge equivalents]

tossups.question: Gareth Evans used the example of a “native” with a ring through his nose to illustrate how thoughts obtain this property. The “asymmetric dependency” theory of this broad concept appears in a work that discusses the inability of frogs to distinguish between flies and bee-bees, which counters the biological theory of Ruth Millikan. An (*) externalist view of this property argues that the thoughts of an exact replica of a philosopher created by lightning would not have this property, since the “swampman” lacks Donald Davidson’s experiences. Frege argued that propositions can differ in this property even when they share a referent since “morning star” and “evening star” have different senses. For 10 points, name this property studied in semantics.
tossups.answer: meaning [or content, or intentionality, or aboutness; accept semantics until mention, prompt on “reference” until mention, prompt on “representation” or other reasonable synonyms; do NOT prompt on or accept “knowledge”]
tossups.answer_formatted: meaning [or content, or intentionality, or aboutness; accept semantics until mention, prompt on “reference” or other reasonable synonyms; do NOT prompt on or accept “knowledge”]

tossups.question: This process in an electron is calculated from velocity and polarization four-vectors as well as the electromagnetic field strength tensor in the Bargmann-Michel-Telegdi equation. One form of this process causes a change in the Pauli-Lubanski pseudovector, and is caused by the composition of two non-collinear Lorentz boosts leading to a Wigner rotation. Relativistic corrections to this process are named after (*) Thomas, de Sitter, and Lense-Thirring, while its Larmor form occurs in magnetic moments. This process was measured for Mercury’s perihelion as a confirmation for general relativity. This process’s angular velocity equals torque over moment of inertia times spin angular velocity; that “torque-induced” type of this process occurs in gyroscopes and tops. For 10 points, name this phenomenon, the change in the axis of rotation of a spinning body.

bonuses.leadin:
Whenever this writer presented historical background information in his novels, he would humorously attribute it
to the scholar “Dryasdust.” For 10 points each:
parts:
Name this author who wrote about the Jacobite rebellion in Waverley and about a knight who marries Rowena
and fights for King Richard the Lionheart in Ivanhoe.

In this novel by Scott, the disinherited Frank Osbaldistone goes to Scotland to track down Rashleigh. The title
Highlander disguises himself as the cattle dealer Campbell and dies saving Frank and his love Diana.

This subseries of Scott’s Waverley novels include The Heart of Midlothian and The Bride of Lammermoor. It
begins with The Black Dwarf, whose introduction claims this collection was edited by Jedediah Cleishbotham.

bonuses.leadin: This person provided an alternative to the geometric theories of Jomini. For 10 points each:
answers: Carl van Clausewitz [or Carl Philipp Gottfried von Clausewitz]
Napoleon Bonaparte [or Napoleon Bonaparte; Emperor Napoleon I]
parts: Name this student of Scharnhorst who theorized a “remarkable trinity” of primordial violence, chance, and subordination to policy while describing a certain activity.

Clausewitz’s On War was greatly influenced by the successes of the wars fought by this French emperor, who savaged the Prussian army at the Battle of Austerlitz. This person received his final defeat at the Battle of Waterloo.

Clausewitz uses this word to describe the factors distinguishing “real war from war on paper.” The fog of war contributes to this aspect, which encompasses the difficulties a commander faces when trying to direct a conflict.
answers_formatted: Carl van Clausewitz [or Carl Philipp Gottfried von Clausewitz]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some things about Hindu goddesses.
parts: This goddess, who was first mentioned in the Rig Veda, is a patroness of wisdom and music. She is often portrayed riding a white hamsa, or swan, and holding a stringed instrument.
This warrior goddess was known for using her shape-shifting abilities to kill the buffalo demon Mahishasura.
Saraswati and Durga are celebrated with this type of event. These events may include washing statues and offering water and incense, and this term also applies to multi-day celebrations.

bonuses.leadin: In this short story, the narrator’s aunt tells him not to love music so much, since it could be taken away from him. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this short story in which Clark takes the former music teacher Georgiana to the title event, where she is extremely moved and declares “I don’t want to go!” back to her dull life in Nebraska.
“A Wagner Matinee” is by this author of O Pioneers! and My Antonia.

In another Cather story, a boy by this name runs away to New York, lives expensively until he goes broke, then throws himself under a train. This is the first name of a poet surnamed Dunbar who wrote “We Wear the Mask.”

bonuses.leadin: Samples are typically placed in a deuterated solvent in a long, thin tube in this technique, which uses tetramethylsilane as a standard. For 10 points each:
answers: DEPT [or Distortionless Enhancement by Polarization Transfer]
parts: Name this technique in which compounds are subjected to a strong magnetic field, and each non-equivalent atom corresponds to a different peak. It comes in hydrogen and carbon-13 varieties.
The chemical shifts in H1 and C13 NMR are usually given in these units.

By applying a pulse at 45, 90, and 135 degrees, this experiment often done as part of carbon-13 NMR is used to determine the number of hydrogens attached to a given carbon. It’s not the attached proton test.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about America’s long history of housing discrimination. For 10 points each:
parts: John McKnight coined the name for this activity, in which investment is denied to certain neighborhoods because of race. This activity gained its name from the color that “Type D” neighborhoods were drawn in.

This New Deal program has been accused of pursuing redlining against African Americans, but recent research has mostly absolved it. FDR created this agency to refinance loans to prevent the collapse of the housing industry.

The 1968 Fair Housing Act, which attempted to prevent housing discrimination based on race and a number of other factors, was passed under this President, whose “Great Society” established Medicare and Medicaid.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about fruit in Roman mythology, for 10 points each:
parts: This goddess was abducted by Pluto and ate six pomegranate seeds while she was in the Underworld, causing her mother Ceres to throw the world into winter for half the year.
This goddess of orchards and fruit trees married Vertumnus after he disguised himself as an old woman to get into her garden.
Vertumnus convinced Pomona to love him by telling her the story of this Greek shepherd, who hanged himself on Anaxarete’s doorstep after she rejected him. She subsequently turned into a statue.

bonuses.leadin: You’re an aspiring molecular biologist who has been asked to clone a fragment of DNA to make an expression vector. For 10 points each:
parts: After analyzing the sequence, you decide to use this class of enzymes that can make specific cuts in the vector plasmid. However, your lab’s inventory is outdated and you realize you do not actually have BamHI and XbaI.

Your neighboring postdoc takes pity on you and recommends that you try his TOPO AT cloning kit. TOPO cloning works because using this kind of DNA polymerase used in PCR will create a 3’ adenine overhang.
Finally, you decide to use this cloning method developed by Invitrogen. This method involves site specific recombination of attP sites and attB sites to create an “entry clone.”

bonuses.leadin: One character in this movie, Torgo, was supposed to be a satyr, but accidentally wore his prosthetics backwards so he just appears to have weirdly massive thighs. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this low-budget horror movie considered one of the worst ever made. It features a lost family getting trapped with a polygamous cult run by “the Master,” who somehow kills people by touching them.

Manos: The Hands of Fate was made infamous by this show. In it, a host and the robots Tom Servo and Crow are trapped on a satellite and forced to watch bad movies until they go insane, but mock the films instead.

This red-haired actress played “third-generation supervillain” Kinga Forrester in the Mystery Science Theater reboot. This founder of Geek and Sundry wrote and starred in The Guild as well as Dr. Horrible’s Sing-Along Blog.

bonuses.leadin: Many philosophes contributed to this work, which was edited by Denis Diderot. For 10 points each:
answers: the Encyclopedia or a Systematic Dictionary of the Sciences, Arts, and Crafts [or Encyclopédie, ou dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers]
parts: Name this massive eighteenth-century reference work that many credited with developing the ideas of the French Enlightenment.
This philosophe was Diderot’s co-editor on the Encyclopedia. Diderot wrote about this man’s “dream” in a namesake set of dialogues.
This most prolific encyclopedist wrote about 17,000 articles for the Encyclopedia, including those for Democracy, France, Government, the Inquisition, Paris, and Superstition.
answers_formatted: the Encyclopedia or a Systematic Dictionary of the Sciences, Arts, and Crafts [or Encyclopédie, ou dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers]
acceptable: the Encyclopedia or a Systematic Dictionary of the Sciences, Arts, and Crafts
Encyclopedia or a Systematic Dictionary of the Sciences, Arts, and Crafts
Encyclopédie, ou dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers

bonuses.leadin: Fritz Kreisler rearranged the third movement of this piece for violin and piano and titled it “Chanson Arabe.” For 10 points each:
answers: Busoni Piano Concerto [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this orchestral work by Rimsky-Korsakov. In the first movement of the piece, the titular Sultana is depicted in an intricate violin solo accompanied by a harp.

This other composer wrote an overture and a song cycle based on the Scheherazade myth. He may be better known for paying homage to his Spanish heritage in Rapsodie Espagnole and Pavane for a Dead Princess.

This lengthy concerto features an offstage male chorus singing the words from Adam Oehlenschlager’s Aladdin in the Cantico final movement. Its tarantella fourth movement is difficult for both the soloist and the orchestra.

bonuses.leadin: This character has a clown who makes fun of him for dragging him through the woods hunting all the time and for falling in love. For 10 points each:
answers: The Recognition of Shakuntala [or Abhijñānashākuntala or Abhijñānaśākuntalam]
parts: Name this character, a king whom Durvasa curses into forgetting his wife until she shows him her signet ring, which unfortunately gets eaten by a fish.
Dushyanta appears in this Kalidasa play, named after his wife, whom he does finally remember in the end.
Shakuntala originally lives in the woods studying under Mother Gautami with this occupation, which Siddhartha legendarily left his father’s palace to practice.

bonuses.leadin: You just signed up for a psychological experiment! Answer some questions about hallucinogens you might be given, for 10 points each:
answers: Project MKUltra [prompt on answers like “the CIA mind control program”]
Marsh Chapel experiment [accept Good Friday experiment]
parts: In this CIA experiment to study LSD’s powers of persuasion, subjects, including soldiers and mental patients, received LSD. It culminated in a CIA-run brothel drugging its clients in Operation Midnight Climax.
In this experiment by Walter Pahnke, theology students reported experiencing genuine religious experiences after receiving psilocybin.

Psychoactive drugs were given to the inhabitants of one of these places in Concord to see how it affected their recidivism rates. Philip Zimbardo ran a famous Stanford experiment modeling one of these places.
answers_formatted: Project MKUltra [prompt on answers like “the CIA mind control program]

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about particle physics, for 10 points each.
parts: This is the most massive fundamental particle discovered to date and was one of two particles proposed to explain CP violation in kaon decay.
The top quark was discovered at the Tevatron, housed at this scientific facility in Illinois. It is named for a scientist who also names a class of particles contrasted with bosons.

This other particle’s mass can be predicted from the mass of the top quark because it has a Yukawa coupling with the left and right handed top quarks. One method of producing it is gluon fusion mediated by a top quark loop.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the history of the nuclear power industry. For 10 points each:
answers: Chernobyl disaster [accept obvious equivalents for “disaster” like “accident”]
parts: This worst nuclear disaster in British history occurred due to a build up of Wigner Energy in graphite piles. This event released a bunch of harmful radioactive material, including iodine-131, in Cumberland.

The first permanent repository for used nuclear fuel in the world is being built in this country. Its subordination of its foreign policy to the USSR under the Paasikivi-Kekkonen doctrine was dubbed “this country” -ization.
This 1986 event was the greatest disaster to hit the nuclear power industry, spreading radiation across Eastern Europe. This event was the subject of an oral history by Svetlana Alexievich.

bonuses.leadin: A billboard displaying this statement appears in the final shot of Howard Hawks’ Scarface above the corpse of a gangster played by Paul Muni. For 10 points each:
answers: a shower [prompt on answers like “gym bathroom,” “hotel bathroom”]
parts: Name this four-word statement that, in the 1983 Scarface remake, is flashed by a zeppelin passing over Tony Montana’s house. At the end of the remake, Tony dies in a pool underneath a statue inscribed with this statement.
The 1983 version of Scarface was directed by this man. The visual style of this director of Carrie, Blow Out and The Untouchables is characterized by slow zooms and split-screens.

Carrie begins with Carrie experiencing her first period in one of these locations. In Hitchcock’s Psycho, shrieking violins play as Marion Crane is brutally stabbed to death in one of these locations within the Bates Motel.
answers_formatted: a shower [prompt on answers like “gym bathroom,” “hotel bathroom]

bonuses.leadin: A series by this author ends with the narrator receiving two dolls in the mail which she and her friend had thrown away. For 10 points each:
answers: brilliant [accept My Brilliant Friend or My Brilliant Career]
parts: Name this reclusive Italian author who wrote about her friendship with Lila and her escape from a poor neighborhood in the Neapolitan Novels. She is possibly the translator Anita Raja.

The first of the Neapolitan Novels describes the precocious Lila as “my [this adjective] friend”. A Miles Franklin novel describes the writing career of the independent-minded Sybylla Melvyn with this adjective.

This other modern Italian author wrote about a geographically-encoded labyrinthine library that burns down during the investigations of William of Baskerville and Adso of Melk in The Name of the Rose.

bonuses.leadin: This event resulted in the death of Ronni Moffit, whose husband was its only survivor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this event in which a Chevy containing employees of the Institute for Policy Studies was bombed on Embassy Row. This was the only state-sponsored act of international terrorism to ever occur in Washington D.C.

The assassination of Orlando Letelier was part of Phase III of this program of state terrorism which targeted alleged leftist “terrorists” and repressed citizens in the countries of the Southern Cone of Latin America.

Operation Condor was the brainchild of Manuel Contreras, who led the infamous DINA secret police of this leader. This person became president of Chile after leading a coup to overthrow Salvador Allende.

bonuses.leadin: For examples of these phenomena where the ratio of amplitude to depth is much less than 1, the Boussinesq approximation is valid. For 10 points each:
answers: ocean waves [accept wind waves or wind-generated waves or any answer that indicates waves propagating in water; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Identify these phenomena, which can be modeled numerically using programs like SWAN and MIKE 21. Their “rogue” type occurs when their height exceeds twice the mean trough to crest height.

Stokes’ criteria for waves to undergo this phenomenon include the crest attaining an angle of 120 degrees and the ratio of the wave height to the wavelength equaling approximately 1/7. Subtypes include surging and collapsing.

This dimensionless number is used to determine whether a breaker is spilling, plunging, surging, or collapsing. It equals the tangent of the bed slope divided by the square root of the wave height over the deep water wavelength.
answers_formatted: ocean waves [accept wind waves or wind-generated waves or any answer that indicates waves propagating in water; prompt on partial answer]
acceptable: any answer that indicates waves propagating in water

bonuses.leadin: Some of this man’s illustrations include a dodo holding a thimble with tiny human hands and a pack of cards flying above a girl. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this long-time satirical cartoonist for Punch, who is better known for showing that girl with a bottle that says “Drink Me” in his illustrations for Alice in Wonderland.

Salvador Dali also illustrated a rare edition of Alice in Wonderland. Characteristically, he turned the Mad Hatter’s tea table into a melting one of these objects, which is found covered in ants in The Persistence of Memory.

This British Surrealist showed crocodiles swimming through a background of galaxies in a painting based on the poem “How Doth the Little Crocodile.” She depicted her relationship with Max Ernst in The Inn of the Dawn.
